Understate: The claim may understate the extent of the legal debate and differing opinions on whether the Geneva Conventions applied to the war on terror before 2005.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no consensus among legal experts regarding whether the Geneva Conventions applied to the war on terror before 2005.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation presented in the form of the Supreme Court ruling in 2006 (Hamdan vs. Rumsfeld) that detainees were entitled to the full protections of the Geneva Conventions, suggesting that the claim may not be entirely accurate.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Bush administration, in a memo signed by President Bush, declared that the Third Geneva Convention did not apply to al-Qaida or Taliban detainees.
Falters at times: The claim may falter at times due to the lack of consensus and conflicting legal opinions on the application of the Geneva Conventions to the war on terror before 2005.
Exaggerate: There is no indication of exaggeration in the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim does not seem to rely on any problematic assumptions.
